title.narrative: Health and rights for People Who Use Drugs in Kyrgyzstan

description.narrative: The programme aims to ends the AIDS epidemic among PWUD in Kyrgyzstan through 1) A strengthened civil society that holds governments to account, 2) Increased fulfiment of human rights of key populations, 3) Improved SRHR and fewer HIV infections. The specific outcomes include: - Government and society respect the PWUD community and they are self-financing, - PWUD community promotes legislative initiatives to respect human rights, - An increased number of social worker (for PWUD and PLWHA) are paid from the state budget, - The availability of high-quality services (geographically, physically and financially and including services for young PWUDs) 1. Women's Centers 2. Rehabilitation centers 3. Consultation and information on new surfactants 4. Psycho-social rehabilitation

We believe that the end of AIDS is possible if there is more focus on key populations. Our project in Kyrgyzstan addresses barriers faced by the PWUD community related to their sexual and reproductive health and rights. Driven by community champions, we work to realize a more supportive drug policy; a strong PWUD community that is respected by society and the government; and increased access to high-quality services for (young) PWUD. The Kyrgyz Republic is a country with low HIV prevalence in the general population. However, between 2006 and 2015, the number of officially registered cases of HIV infections in the country rose 5.7 times to a total number of 6,402 people living with HIV. Key populations carry a heavy burden of the epidemic, for example the HIV prevalence among people who inject drugs (PWID) is 12,4%. Injecting drug use is the primary driver of HIV infection in the Kyrgyz Republic, where more than 50% of HIV infections occur in PWID. One of the reasons that there has been some increase is the limited access to prevention programmes and healthcare for key populations. For the last four years, the overall political situation in Kyrgyzstan has been fragile and dynamic at the same time. The year 2014 was marked by a troubling trend in the country, as the government failed to promote and consolidate political and civil rights that many had hoped would follow the 2010 constitutional reforms and change of government. The rise of religious and radical nationalistic movements has led to sporadic cases of discrimination and violence against key populations. The spring of 2016 brought long-awaited positive changes, when the country’s parliament finally declined a draft law on “foreign agents” due to strong political pressure.
We focus on People Who Use Drugs. So far 30 community members have been trained, 3000 persons have been reached with information and 1500 received full package of services.

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

description.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

comment.narrative: The following meetings and conferences were attended: the Bridging the Gaps Learning Institute (Bishkek, March 2018), the Eastern Europe and Central Asia conference (April 2018, Moscow), The International AIDS Conference (July 2018, Amsterdam), and the regional Autumn School (October, Kyiv).

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services

description.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services (disaggregated by age) everything falling under voluntary counselling and testing is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services

description.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services (disaggregated by age) ART, STI and TB treatment

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (condom distribution)

description.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (disaggregated by age) (condom distribution)

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services

description.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services (disaggregated by age) including self-help groups, psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

title.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services

description.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services (disaggregated by age)

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years.

description.narrative: Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services

# of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).

comment.narrative: 15 professionals working at NGOs and 50 teachers have been trained.

description.narrative: 2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services

comment.narrative: the legal service providers all work at NGOs
